misconceptions.name: Implemented a different program instead of the required number guessing game
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a road trip cost calculator rather than a number guessing game with a random secret number, guesses in a loop, and high/low feedback as required by the prompt.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that submitting any working Java program (in this case, a road trip cost calculator) is acceptable, even if it does not implement the specified number guessing game.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must implement the described number guessing game: generate a random integer between 1 and 100, repeatedly prompt the user to guess until correct, and after each wrong guess provide "Too high" or "Too low" feedback, then report the number of guesses.
symptoms: No use of Random or any random number generation
No loop to allow repeated guessing
No conditional logic comparing a guess to a secret number
Program inputs distance, MPG, and fuel price instead of a guessed number
Output describes driving cost rather than guessing feedback
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely misreading the assignment or reusing code from a different exercise without adapting it to the current problem specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and design a new program specifically for the number guessing game: declare a Random object to pick an int from 1 to 100, use a while loop to read guesses until the user is correct, compare each guess with the secret, and print "Too high" or "Too low" accordingly.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program solves a different problem (road trip cost) and contains none of the structural elements of a number guessing game, indicating a clear mismatch with the prompt.

evidence.note: The code implements a cost-of-driving calculator with distance, MPG, and fuel price inputs, and has no random number, guessing loop, or high/low feedback required for the number guessing game.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Program Logic/Structure
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a completely different program (Road Trip Cost Calculator) instead of the required Number Guessing Game. None of the core concepts required by the assignment (Random number generation, loops, conditionals for high/low feedback) are present.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student either misunderstood the assignment requirements or submitted the wrong file, as the provided code calculates the cost of a road trip rather than implementing an interactive guessing game.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must initialize a secret number (1-100), enter a guessing loop, read user input, check input against the secret number, and provide appropriate 'Too high' or 'Too low' feedback until the correct guess ends the loop.
symptoms: Program asks for distance, MPG, and price instead of a guess.
Program outputs a cost instead of game feedback.
Absence of loops and randomization components.
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to follow assignment instructions or selecting the wrong file for submission.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the assignment prompt carefully and implement the required features: random number generation, input loop, and conditional logic.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code clearly implements an entirely different, identifiable task (calculating travel cost) and contains zero elements required for the assignment (Number Guessing Game).

evidence.note: The class name suggests a non-game purpose.
Variable declarations are for cost calculation, not game tracking (e.g., answer, guess, count).
Mathematical logic for calculating travel cost, completely unrelated to a guessing game.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Solved
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for a completely different problem (RoadTripCost calculator) instead of the Number Guessing Game required by Q2.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted code from a different assignment or misunderstood which problem they were solving.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Q2 requires implementing a number guessing game where the computer generates a random number 1-100 and the user guesses repeatedly until correct, with feedback on whether each guess is too high or too low.
symptoms: Code calculates road trip cost instead of implementing a guessing game
No Random class or random number generation
No loop for repeated guessing
No comparison logic or feedback for guesses
Program terminates after single calculation
misconceptions.root_cause: Student submitted incorrect assignment code - either confusion about which problem to solve, copy-paste error, or file management mistake.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Verify you are solving Q2 (Number Guessing Game). Start fresh with: (1) import Random and Scanner, (2) generate random number 1-100, (3) use a loop to repeatedly read guesses, (4) compare each guess and provide feedback, (5) exit when guess matches.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence - the entire submission addresses a different problem entirely with no elements of the guessing game.

evidence.note: Entire program solves a road trip cost calculation problem, not the number guessing game required by Q2. No random number generation, no guessing loop, no game logic.

misconceptions.name: No random number generation / wrong program implemented
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a road trip cost calculator instead of a number guessing game and did not generate any random number between 1 and 100. Rubric score for this criterion: 0/1.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the task is to compute the cost of a road trip using distance, MPG, and fuel price, rather than to create a number guessing game with a random secret number.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should create a guessing game where the computer picks a random integer between 1 and 100 (e.g., using Random and nextInt(100) + 1) and uses that value as the hidden answer for the user to guess.
symptoms: No Random object is declared or used
No variable stores a secret number between 1 and 100
All inputs relate to distance, MPG, and price instead of a guessed number
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion about the assignment prompt or reuse of code from a different exercise.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Discard or set aside the road trip cost code, reread the prompt, and start by declaring a Random object and an int answer = rand.nextInt(100) + 1 to represent the secret number.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code solves a completely different problem and contains no random-related constructs at all.

evidence.note: Program declares only Scanner and double variables for a cost calculation; there is no Random object or int answer variable.

misconceptions.name: Missing guessing loop
misconceptions.description: The program does not include any loop to allow repeated guesses; it simply reads three numeric inputs once and exits. Rubric score for this criterion: 0/1.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that reading a fixed set of inputs once and computing a single result is sufficient for this task.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The guessing game should use a loop (e.g., while or do-while) so that the user can repeatedly guess until they find the correct number.
symptoms: No while, do-while, or for loop in the program
Program flow is strictly linear: input distance, MPG, price, compute cost, print once, then exit
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the assignment as a one-shot calculation instead of an interactive, repeated-guess game.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce a while or do-while loop that continues prompting for guesses until the user enters the secret number.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The file contains no loop constructs; all logic is a straight line from input to output.

evidence.note: All statements execute once in sequence; there is no looping structure for repeated guesses.

misconceptions.name: Missing 'Too high' feedback logic
misconceptions.description: The program does not compare a user guess to a secret number and never outputs a 'Too high' hint or any equivalent conditional feedback. Rubric score for this criterion: 0/1.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that no conditional feedback on guesses is required, since there are no guesses at all.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The game should use an if/else (or similar) statement to compare the guess with the secret number and print 'Too high' when the guess is greater than the answer.
symptoms: No if or else statements in the entire program
Output is always a single cost line with no conditional branching
No comparison between a user-entered number and a secret answer
misconceptions.root_cause: The student implemented a non-interactive numeric calculation rather than a game that evaluates guesses.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After reading a guess, add conditional logic: if (guess > answer) { System.out.println("Too high!"); }.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There are no conditional constructs or game-related messages; only a fixed cost message is printed.

evidence.note: The only output is the cost message; there is no conditionally printed 'Too high' or similar hint.

misconceptions.name: Missing 'Too low' feedback logic
misconceptions.description: The program does not implement any logic to detect when a guess is below the secret number and therefore never outputs a 'Too low' hint. Rubric score for this criterion: 0/1.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears not to recognize the requirement to guide the user with 'Too low' messages after incorrect guesses.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The code should compare each guess with the secret number and print 'Too low' whenever the guess is less than the answer.
symptoms: No branching on a guessed value
Program has no messages related to 'Too low' or guesses in general
misconceptions.root_cause: Same as for the 'Too high' logic: the student implemented a single calculation instead of an interactive guessing process.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Within the guessing loop, add a branch like: else if (guess < answer) { System.out.println("Too low!"); }.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absence of any conditionals or hint messages in the provided code.

evidence.note: Inputs are distance, MPG, and price, not guesses; there is no place where a guess could be compared as 'too low'.

misconceptions.name: No termination condition based on a correct guess
misconceptions.description: The program terminates after computing and printing a cost, not based on detecting a correct guess, and does not track the number of guesses. Rubric score for this criterion: 0/1.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the program should simply finish after one calculation, without a goal state like 'correct guess'.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The game should continue prompting for guesses until the user enters the correct secret number, then terminate and report that the guess was correct (optionally with the number of attempts).
symptoms: No variable representing a guess count or a success condition
Program always terminates immediately after printing the cost line
No 'Correct!' message or equivalent success output
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to model the game as a loop with a clear winning condition tied to user input.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Use a boolean or loop condition tied to (guess != answer); when guess == answer, print a 'Correct!' message with the number of attempts and exit the loop.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is no state or logic for guesses at all; termination is unconditional after one print.

evidence.note: The program ends right after printing the cost and closing the scanner, with no condition based on user correctness.

misconceptions.name: Complete disregard of the assignment prompt
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program for calculating road trip costs instead of the required Number Guessing Game. None of the core concepts (random number generation, loops, conditionals for high/low hints, specific termination) related to the assignment task were implemented.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have copied or submitted code for a completely different assignment (Road Trip Cost Calculator) instead of implementing the Number Guessing Game requested in Q2.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must implement the logic of the Number Guessing Game, including generating a random number, setting up a guessing loop, and providing hints based on comparison operators.
symptoms: Code calculates fuel cost instead of simulating a game
Missing random number generation
Missing loop structure
Missing conditional logic (if/else) for high/low checks
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding or confusion about which problem to solve, or mistakenly submitting the wrong file/code.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the assignment prompt carefully and delete the current code. Focus on implementing the required logic: 1. Generate the secret number. 2. Use a loop to repeatedly ask for input. 3. Use if/else statements inside the loop to check the guess against the secret number and provide feedback.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The supplied code, 'RoadTripCost', is completely unrelated to the 'Number Guessing Game' task.

evidence.note: The entire program is dedicated to calculating fuel cost, not playing a guessing game.
